Award.AwardTitle: Fifteenth International Conference on the Science and Application of Nanotubes (NT14), June 2-6, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides partial support for graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, and junior faculty to attend the Fifeenth International Conference on the Science and Applications Of Nanotubes (NT14) to be held at the University of Southern California in June 2014. This annual international conference is being held in the US for the first time in a decade and will span a wide range of topics including chemical separation techniques, materials science, and thermal and solar energy conversion that are of interest to CMP researchers. Many of the topics covered in this conference will address the key research challenges facing the community at large, such as inhomogeneity of carbon synthesis, toxicity, and utilization of carbon nanotubes in large integrated circuits. The conference will attract a broad audience, which includes world leaders in nanotube and carbon physics and condensed-matter physics (including several Nobel Laureates), emerging academic stars, and young researchers at graduate and early post-graduate levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Fifteenth International Conference on the Science and Application of Nanotubes (NT14) was held at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles, California on June 2-6, 2014. NT14 upheld the NT tradition of presenting the latest results in the science and applications of nanotubes and related materials in plenary sessions. Emphasis was given to convivial poster sessions and student participation. Over 225 participants attended the conference, including students, post-docs, faculty, and members from industry. A total of 45 talks were presented, as well as 157 posters. A complete list of abstracts can be found at http://nt14.org/.

 

This conference featured many world-renown invited speakers presenting thier cutting edge research on carbon nanotubes and related materials. The topics covered in this conference covered a wide range including chemical separation techniques, materials science, and thermal and solar energy conversion. Many of the topics covered in this conference addressed the key research challenges facing the community at large, such as inhomogeneity of carbon synthesis, toxicity, and utilization of carbon nanotubes in large integrated circuits. NSF funds were used to support student participation in this conference series, as we recognize that this inclusion is important in developing the next generation of innovators, and hence, continued growth of the field. 

 

Since 1999, this conference on the science and technology of carbon nanotubes is held every year in a different country, and it has not been held in the US for the past 10 years. These technical conferences serve a very important purpose in bringing together a larger scientific community to exchange ideas and act as a catalyst for further research advancement. This conference draws scientists from many disciplines including chemistry, materials science, biology, physics, electrical engineering, as well as industry. This type of interdisciplinary exchange is crucial for the continued growth the field at large.
